The movie is bad because its script teeters on clich√©s and forced situations, failing to build characters with clear motivations or a narrative arc that's even remotely interesting. The plot, which attempts to explore dynamics of power and desire, fizzles into a succession of scenes that don't quite connect, leaving the viewer with a feeling of emptiness and confusion. The characters, far from generating empathy or fascination, come across as unsympathetic, and their actions lack solid justification, making any kind of emotional investment in their fates difficult. It even generates embarrassment, a palpable cringe at the forced nature of their interactions and decisions. The chemistry between the protagonists is conspicuously lacking, making the film's central relationship feel artificial and unbelievable, stripping it of the tension or appeal it was intended to generate. Despite its attempt to enter the realm of an erotic thriller, the film fails miserably to create a sensual or exciting atmosphere. The intimate scenes lack the necessary intensity and feel more like a passionless formality, often creating an uncomfortable and artificial feeling. Compared to other offerings in the genre, "Baby Girl" pales in every respect, offering an unsatisfactory cinematic experience that fails to provoke or entertain. Nicole Kidman's talent, though present, is overshadowed by the overall weakness of the project, leaving her performance as an isolated effort amid a disjointed ensemble that, at times, borders on the ridiculous and produces that feeling of "cringe" so characteristic of poorly executed situations. Ultimately, the film comes across as a failed attempt to generate controversy and eroticism, remaining a superficial and forgettable offering that, at times, is downright embarrassing to watch.

Babygirl had the potential to explore some deep and emotionally charged themes, but unfortunately, it fell flat for me. While the erotic scenes were well executed and visually appealing, they couldn't make up for the weak plot and lack of emotional depth. The dynamic between the sub and dom characters lacked authenticity, and I didn‚Äôt get the sense that either party was truly educated in the lifestyle. It felt like the filmmakers only scratched the surface of what could have been a complex and layered power exchange. Emotionally, the movie missed the mark. The pain and betrayal of being cheated on were barely addressed, making the character's motivations feel shallow and unrealistic. Given the protagonist's age, I expected more maturity in how she communicated, especially with her husband. Instead, her reactions often felt impulsive and teenage-like, which undermined the gravity of the situation. The film also gave off the vibe of a low-budget production, and not just in terms of visuals ‚Äî the storytelling itself felt underdeveloped. There was so much room for deeper dialogue, emotional reckoning, and stronger character arcs, but none of that was fully realized. In the end, while Babygirl might satisfy those looking purely for steamy content, those hoping for a compelling story with emotional weight and mature handling of serious topics might be left disappointed.

For one, that I‚Äôm still thinking about this movie days after watching it says something. There are definitely scenes I had to watch through my hands because they made me so uncomfortable. Nevertheless it‚Äôs quite compelling. I particularly found it interesting that Samuel and Romy were exploring the concept of domination and submission with neither really knowing what they were doing but deciding to give to a shot and figure it out along the way. I am not a part of that community so perhaps that is a recipe for disaster, but there was something about their willingness to trust each other enough to try it on that I found intriguing. At some point everyone is a beginner. It wasn‚Äôt until close to the end of their relationship that they discussed a safe word. And also the fact that it was more of a relationship that I think is considered a switch, where at times we see Samuel being submissive. At one point during pillow talk Romy tells Samuel that he‚Äôs great at sensing what people need and giving that to him and we see him doing just that for Jacob, Romy‚Äôs husband, while he is having a panic attack. I found their chemistry and dynamic quite compelling and while continuing the relationship wouldn‚Äôt make sense, it still feels like mourning a loss when we discover Samuel has taken a job in Japan. But we can see the lasting effects of their relationship when Romy needs to fantasize about him in order to derive pleasure in her marriage. Kidman is fantastic, though something about the rave scene reminded me of Naomi Watts in Gypsy so I can envision her in this same role. That‚Äôs not to discredit Kidman, it was just a fleeting thought. To me the star was Dickinson. He was the perfect choice for Samuel and has me intrigued. This could also be because he was an actor I haven‚Äôt seen before. And I already know how talented Kidman is.

Some says it was horrible, some finds it "sexy", some finds it "kinky". It probably is all of it. But what intrigued me more is the family dynamics vs female sexuality...why is that we, women are judged so harshly for our fantasies? Why do we feel ashamed by our dark desires? Why do we have to be judged at all? Why having family and husband often means end of weird, kinky, dirty sex? I think as society we asks wrong questions. She loved her husband, and he loved her. They were great together, but hardly ever one person can GIVEITALL...it probably works better if you put a few people together: husband. Friend, lover... if you were lucky enough to find it in one men-congrats but the truth is-it hardly ever happens to the rest of us. Why we have society of ashamed, hungry and scared people? Why and when did we convinced each other that you absolutely MUST have one and only one person for the rest of your life? We created unrealistic expectations of ourselves and when they fall on our heads we feel like biggest looser and failure. We beg to be forgiven. But for what exactly? She wanted to be SEEN. She wanted to feel accepted for what she wanted, even though she was scared to admit what it is, that she really wanted...we carry in ourselves the need for love, for acceptance but also need for punishment, humiliation, pain...these are blurred together. Most of us never experiments with the hidden side of our inner urges, those few who dose-get to meet antother unknown side of themselves. I think what we should do, is be more open, do not judge and most importantly-stop putting ourselves unto position of failure-like lifelong marriages.

Spoiler Alert: The acting made this movie. The storyline is a bit of a stretch for some people because this is not how see women and definitely not how society wants to see women, which I feel is the point. And the point of making it so visceral. We see men in Kidman‚Äôs role all the time, as the older leader with a younger subordinate and power dynamics, but we don‚Äôt see this as often with women. When we do, it viewed as awkward and wrong, even. Yet we don‚Äôt tend to view men in these roles quite as wrong or awkward because we see it so much. It‚Äôs normalized. Kidman does an amazing job showing how she wants to be a certain way, sexually, but struggles to find that with her husband, but is caught in wanting to be how she thinks he wants her to be. Women ignore real desires and the struggle to communicate those desire to partners is real, even in long term marriages, hence some of the awkward moments in bed with her husband. Banderas Is extraordinary in showing his love for his wife being playful and supportive, and the pain when she admits the affair is so well done. It‚Äôs nice to see men caring and feeling that deeply and still not making it about them. He stays and in the end listens and wants to understand. For me, this movie is far less about the the affair and more about the dynamics women‚Äôs sexuality and relationships. This FEELS like a movie directed by a woman and Reijn hits it out of the park. I could not love Banderas and Kidman more for taking such a leap in exploring this role and making it come to life is real and emotional way. If you‚Äôre not giving this a 10/10 then you many need to watch again with different focus.

Babygirl (2024) is yet another attempt at making a "provocative" drama that leans too much on surface-level shock value rather than compelling storytelling. The plot, if you can call it that, revolves around an imbalanced relationship dynamic that lacks any real emotional depth. There is no real buildup, no effort to make the audience care about these characters beyond their physical interactions, and certainly no originality. The film tries to be daring, but instead, it feels like a predictable series of events with little payoff. The directing is uninspired, relying on overused shaky cam techniques that have no business in a drama like this. The cinematography does nothing to elevate the story, and at times, it feels like the camera is as lost as the script. The only real standout performance comes from Antonio Banderas, but he's barely in the movie. Nicole Kidman, despite her talent, is stuck in a role that feels more about aesthetics than substance. And of course, we have the usual over-the-top praise for a "bold sexualized performance," the same kind of overhyped reaction we saw with Demi Moore in Substance, as if established actors being in explicit scenes somehow qualifies as groundbreaking cinema. The script is painfully weak, with dialogue that does little to make the characters feel real or relatable. The film spends too much time trying to push a message without taking the time to craft an engaging narrative. There are moments where it seems like it might go somewhere interesting, but then it falls back into the same repetitive themes. The pacing is another issue, dragging through unnecessary moments while rushing past anything that could have added depth. The score is outright annoying. It doesn't complement the film or enhance any of the scenes, it's just there, adding to the discomfort in all the wrong ways. In the end, Babygirl tries to be provocative but lacks the intelligence or creativity to make an impact. It's the kind of movie that confuses shock value with substance, leaving you wondering what the point of it all was.

Babygirl is an interesting and intriguing film, but I believe it falls short in a few areas. It smoulders but never truly catches fire. It's an erotic thriller with some great scenes though. Romy is a successful woman who is CEO of a robotics company in New York. Her husband is a theatre director and they have two teenage children. But at the beginning of the film we are shown that Romy is sexually frustrated. When a new group of interns are brought to her company we see her take an interest in one of them, Samuel. He takes up her interest and soon they begin an affair, where he plays the dominant role. It's torrid and messy and threatens her seemingly stable family life. The film though doesn't quite fulfill its promise. It's not dark enough to work properly as a thriller and we don'tget close enough to the characters to work as a psychological study. Although falling short the performances are very good. Nicole Kidman and Harris Dickinson are both quite good in the lead roles. An interesting film, but not quite a successful one.

Kidman's character here, Romy, is finally addressing her sexual fulfillment 'needs' and is beginning to affirm herself, shedding the shame she's felt all her life. Nicole Kidman, Antonio Banderas, and Harris Dickinson A seductive thriller by director Halina Reign A woman Romy is a high powered CEO of a robotics process automation company She‚Äôs married and has two children Things start to change though when she starts having an affair with a much younger man Samuel, an intern no doubt The exchanges between them go from professional to flirtatious to confrontational to unsettling Romy in a way starts to enjoy Samuel‚Äôs hostility as a form of foreplay, any minute he can implode her world revealing their secret but she can‚Äôt stop being drawn to his demeanor There‚Äôs a lot of stuff in here about being submissive, surrendering control, the lack of intimacy while also being intimate, searching for alternative ways to please ourselves when we lack it, actually understanding what consent is, who actually abuses who, what makes a great leader especially for women, we can unexpectedly gain more courage and confidence when facing what we‚Äôre afraid to do we wouldn‚Äôt normally do It‚Äôs also very adult when it comes to the seduction scenes There are a lot of dialogue exchanges keep in mind and I was expecting a lot more crazy melodrama But the performances by Kidman and Dickinson are solid and Reijn‚Äôs direction takes a look at desires, power dynamics, personal growth, and the struggles of women between the boardroom and the bedroom

Despite reading numerous positive reviews, the film was disappointing for the most part: The characters‚Äô internal and psychological reasoning and grounding was paper thin. Backstories and personal drives were sprinkled so sparsely throughout the story that it seemed like cheap skating, narratively speaking. And while characters were lacking in grounded and relatable personality traits and psychology, neither did they seem to transform or develop in any meaningful way. Harry Dickinson‚Äôs role was without any meaningful depth, his moods and actions inexplicably change without connecting to any deeper layers of the character, and it ends up simply being annoying. The same is nearly true for Nicole Kidman‚Äôs Romy, however we learn that her reasoning behind jeopardising her family and career boils down to her not being able to org**m with her husband of 19 years‚Ä¶ and without spoiling too much; let‚Äôs say the film had a happy, although idle and insubstantial, ending. The stars given is to the sound design, the short moments of funny awkwardness, and Antonio Banderas‚Äô irresistibly charming accent and good acting.

When the Babygirl trailer dropped, I felt like this was a story about a middle aged woman navigating being in a position of power in her profession and exploring the complex layers of being in power/control in some aspects of your life as a woman while not fully feeling empowered in other aspects of your life and how those coexist‚Ä¶namely your sexuality. In a way, Babygirl did that but fell flat a bit. Though Nicole Kidman and Harris Dickinson have chemistry, the characters were not fleshed out enough for that to be transmitted to the viewer. Very little background is given to Dickinson‚Äôs character of Samuel. While Babygirl doesn‚Äôt center Samuel, it would‚Äôve been great to have more of a story to understand his motivations in relation to Romy (Kidman) and her journey. Because of how little the character is fleshed out, he just seems to pop in and out. The ending of the film could‚Äôve felt complete if Samuel‚Äôs point of view could‚Äôve at least been hinted at. The film needed to show the audience more of Romy‚Äôs journey in finding her sexuality after being married for so long so it didn‚Äôt fall flat and came across as just a movie about an affair with a power imbalance and really given us this intense erotic thriller about exploring your sexuality and pleasure later in life and the need to engage with someone new out of fear of judgement. *Babygirl* (2024), directed by Halina Reijn, attempts to position itself as a provocative erotic thriller but ultimately stumbles in its portrayal of BDSM dynamics, misrepresenting the very foundation of what makes such relationships work. While Nicole Kidman‚Äôs performance as Romy Mathis carries the film with elegance and intensity, the movie falls apart in its exploration of power, trust, and intimacy, instead leaning into harmful stereotypes that feel both shallow and irresponsible. At the core of the story is the relationship between Romy and Samuel (Harris Dickinson), which is framed as an exploration of dominance and submission but fails to capture the essential principles of the BDSM community‚Äîtrust, communication, and consent. Samuel is portrayed as the embodiment of a "bad Dom," using manipulation and exploitation instead of fostering a consensual and respectful power dynamic. Meanwhile, Romy is cast as submissive, but her character never actually aligns with what being a willing and active participant in such a dynamic entails. Instead, her actions and reactions feel forced, as though the script misunderstands submission as passivity or victimhood. What‚Äôs most frustrating is the film‚Äôs insistence on framing these interactions as seductive or empowering, while the reality feels exploitative and devoid of the care that should define such relationships. In this way, *Babygirl* not only mishandles BDSM but sensationalizes it in a way that feels outdated and, frankly, lazy. It‚Äôs particularly damning when the film makes *Fifty Shades of Grey*‚Äîoften critiqued for its own shortcomings‚Äîlook like a more authentic representation in comparison. While Kidman delivers a layered and emotionally charged performance, it‚Äôs not enough to salvage a story that fundamentally misunderstands the very subject matter it claims to explore. For those familiar with or part of the BDSM community, *Babygirl* is likely to come across as reductive and tone-deaf, reducing a complex and consensual lifestyle to a series of tired clich√©s. Ultimately, the film is a missed opportunity‚Äîits glossy exterior masks a hollow and uninformed core.

What you are picking up on is sexual tension, and because our culture is so repressed, it‚Äôs making you uncomfortable. Which is good‚Äîit made me uncomfortable too! It‚Äôs good for us to be challenged and made to feel things by the films we watch, and that‚Äôs also a testament to the director and the actors and the crew. So to get on with my actual review, the acting was incredible, the score was incredible, the dynamics between the characters were incredible, and I loved the climactic scene too. The direction was amazing‚Äîmuch like the central character, as the film is getting going I as an audience member was also hesitant.
